title: Home where killer Dennis Nilsen slaughtered male prostitutes goes on the market for £500,000 in plush London suburb
text:
News House of horrors where serial killer chopped up and cooked male prostitutes goes on the market for £500,000 The two-bed flat in Muswell Hill is on sale for more than £30,000 above the average asking price for the area Share Dennis Nilsen's flat 23, Cranley Gardens, Muswell Hill, north London (Photo: Rightmove / Paul Simon) Share   
The house of horrors where sick serial killer Dennis Nilsen murdered and cooked male prostitutes has gone on the market for £500,000. 
The flat, in London's plush suburb of Muswell Hill, north London, is on sale for more than £30,000 above average the asking price for the area - despite its grisly past . 
The home was the subject of a massive police investigation in the 1980s after reports of a strange smell coming from the drains. 
According to its listing on RightMove, the 639sqft fully refurbished flat boasts its own entrance and access to local nature trails. 
The advert adds: "Being able to walk to Highgate tube gives us an easy commute to work or for socialising. Dennis Nilsen murdered and cooked male escorts The home was the subject of a massive police investigation after reports of a strange smell coming from the drains (Photo: Rightmove / Paul Simon) 
"Our separate private entrance and south facing garden allow privacy and makes it feel more like a house." 
The home has been knocked down from its original asking price of £525,000 after it failed to sell. 
Yet it has shot up by almost £200,000 in less than two years after it was extended from a one-bed to a two-bed. 
The house was last sold in 2013 for around £370,000 after undergoing drastic refurbishment and has since been extended to accommodate two bedroosms. Read More 
From 1978 to 1983, Jobcentre clerk Nilsen, now 71, killed at least 15 men and boys he lured to two homes, carving up and boiling the remains then flushing them away or hiding them. 
His killing spree was only found out when an engineer investigating smelly blocked drains found human remains. Dennis Nilsen's killing spree was only found out when an engineer investigating smelly blocked drains found human remains (Photo: Rightmove / Paul Simon) 
Cops were called in after the grim discovery in February 1983 and a police search then turned up three men’s bodies in a wardrobe, tea chest and chest of drawers. 
Nilsen, who killed most of his victims at another flat in Cricklewood, north London, got life in 1983 and has been told he will die in jail. 
He would prey on young homeless gay men and rent boys whom he did not think would be missed by their families, attracting them with the promise of food or alcohol. 
After strangling them, he would store them in his flat, often for months – taking them from underneath floorboards, unwrapping them from plastic and curtains, and lying with them to watch television, listen to music or masturbate. 
When he moved to the attic flat in Muswell Hill on October 5 1981, Nilsen had already killed between nine and 12 young men. 
Before his capture 16 months later he would lure another three there and murder them. Like us on Facebook
